repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: cache paths are derived by replacing each reserved/filesystem-
path-sensitive char with a `%` char in the original path. With this
method, two different files at two different paths (each containing `%`
chars) can erroneously resolve to the very same cache path in certain
edge-cases.

Solution: derive cache paths by url-encoding the original (path) instead
using `vim.uri_encode()` with `"rfc2396"`. Increment `Loader.VERSION` to
denote this change.

comment_data.body: We want to remove `vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup` since it's not easy to add type annotations for. Is it possible to remove this?

```suggestion
  local ret = ('%s/%s'):format(M.path, name:gsub('[/\\:%%]', M.charmap))  -- URL-encode the path.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -99,7 +103,7 @@ end
 ---@return string file_name
 ---@private
 function Loader.cache_file(name)
-  local ret = M.path .. '/' .. name:gsub('[/\\:]', '%%')
+  local ret = ('%s/%s'):format(M.path, name:gsub('[/\\:%%]', M.charmap))

comment_data.body:
Why is this exposed in the public API? Can it be local? That would also remove the need for `@nodoc`

```suggestion
local charmap = {
```

Yeah, I only made it public (and added the reverse lookup) because I thought that users could potentially be able to make use of it. E.g. it provides info on what chars get converted, and could be used via `cachepath:gsub("%%..", vim.loader.charmap)` to derive the original path. Although this could be accomplished without a `vim.loader.charmap` too of course.

Part of what motivated me to put those things in was thinking about how to maintain my own cache on a regular basis. An idea I came up with was to make a script that goes through the cache dir and checks each filename in order to see if its original still exists (and then removing the cached/compiled file if it doesn't).

Lmk what you think. If this is all too far-fetched I can make it local.

That is interesting, but then maybe we should expose these existing uri_encode/uri_decode functions and use those instead: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ccf328172bac2b02f9bd19fa58e105958514a28a/runtime/lua/vim/uri.lua#L19

> Use the same percent-encoding that is done for URLs, but modified to encode a different set of "reserved" characters.

Why is it necessary to have different reserved chars? This prevents using `uri.uri_encode`.

> Why is it necessary to have different reserved chars? This prevents using `uri.uri_encode`.

Oh I didn't see that function. I suppose that should probably be used along with the `rfc2396` pattern. The only real downside I can think of would be somewhat longer filenames due to encoding more chars; idk if that would cause or lead to any issues in-practice...probably not?

> The only real downside I can think of would be somewhat longer filenames due to encoding more chars

If we are worried about that then we need a different approach altogether, like a compression function :) 

However, this does raise the point that we should raise an error/warning if a platform-specific path limit is exceeded. That could be a followup PR if it is out of scope here.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,31 +39,31 @@ do
   local function percent_encode_char(char)
     return '%' .. tohex(sbyte(char), 2)
   end
-  uri_encode = function(text, rfc)
-    if not text then
-      return
-    end
+
+  --- URI-encodes a string using percent escapes.
+  ---@param str string string to encode
+  ---@param rfc "rfc2396" | "rfc2732" | "rfc3986" | nil
+  ---@return string encoded string
+  function M.uri_encode(str, rfc)
     local pattern = PATTERNS[rfc] or PATTERNS.rfc3986
-    return text:gsub('([' .. pattern .. '])', percent_encode_char)
+    return (str:gsub('([' .. pattern .. '])', percent_encode_char))

@@ -3,20 +3,24 @@
 -- https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2732
 -- https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2396
 
-local uri_decode
+local M = {}
+
 do
   local schar = string.char
 
   --- Convert hex to char
   local function hex_to_char(hex)
     return schar(tonumber(hex, 16))
   end
-  uri_decode = function(str)
-    return str:gsub('%%([a-fA-F0-9][a-fA-F0-9])', hex_to_char)
+
+  --- URI-decodes a string containing percent escapes.
+  ---@param str string string to decode
+  ---@return string decoded string
+  function M.uri_decode(str)
+    return (str:gsub('%%([a-fA-F0-9][a-fA-F0-9])', hex_to_char))

comment_data.body: I don't think this `do` block is necessary.

```suggestion
  --- URI-decodes a string containing percent escapes.
  --- @param str string string to decode
  --- @return string decoded string
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3,20 +3,24 @@
 -- https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2732
 -- https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2396
 
-local uri_decode
+local M = {}
+
 do
   local schar = string.char
 
   --- Convert hex to char
   local function hex_to_char(hex)
     return schar(tonumber(hex, 16))
   end
-  uri_decode = function(str)
-    return str:gsub('%%([a-fA-F0-9][a-fA-F0-9])', hex_to_char)
+
+  --- URI-decodes a string containing percent escapes.
+  ---@param str string string to decode
+  ---@return string decoded string

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  --- URI-encodes a string using percent escapes.
  --- @param str string string to encode
  --- @param rfc "rfc2396" | "rfc2732" | "rfc3986" | nil
  --- @return string encoded string
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,31 +39,31 @@ do
   local function percent_encode_char(char)
     return '%' .. tohex(sbyte(char), 2)
   end
-  uri_encode = function(text, rfc)
-    if not text then
-      return
-    end
+
+  --- URI-encodes a string using percent escapes.
+  ---@param str string string to encode
+  ---@param rfc "rfc2396" | "rfc2732" | "rfc3986" | nil
+  ---@return string encoded string

comment_data.body:
I put these extra parenthesis because `gsub()` returns multiple values on success, but only the 1st value is the result string.

> Returns a copy of s in which all (or the first n, if given) occurrences of the pattern have been replaced by a replacement string specified by repl, which can be a string, a table, or a function. gsub also returns, as its second value, the total number of matches that occurred.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,31 +39,31 @@ do
   local function percent_encode_char(char)
     return '%' .. tohex(sbyte(char), 2)
   end
-  uri_encode = function(text, rfc)
-    if not text then
-      return
-    end
+
+  --- URI-encodes a string using percent escapes.
+  ---@param str string string to encode
+  ---@param rfc "rfc2396" | "rfc2732" | "rfc3986" | nil
+  ---@return string encoded string
+  function M.uri_encode(str, rfc)
     local pattern = PATTERNS[rfc] or PATTERNS.rfc3986
-    return text:gsub('([' .. pattern .. '])', percent_encode_char)
+    return (str:gsub('([' .. pattern .. '])', percent_encode_char))

comment_data.body: Ok good to know. That kind of thing can trip up anyone. Maybe worth adding a comment?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,31 +39,31 @@ do
   local function percent_encode_char(char)
     return '%' .. tohex(sbyte(char), 2)
   end
-  uri_encode = function(text, rfc)
-    if not text then
-      return
-    end
+
+  --- URI-encodes a string using percent escapes.
+  ---@param str string string to encode
+  ---@param rfc "rfc2396" | "rfc2732" | "rfc3986" | nil
+  ---@return string encoded string
+  function M.uri_encode(str, rfc)
     local pattern = PATTERNS[rfc] or PATTERNS.rfc3986
-    return text:gsub('([' .. pattern .. '])', percent_encode_char)
+    return (str:gsub('([' .. pattern .. '])', percent_encode_char))

comment_data.body:
Before 0.10 release we should move all these to a `vim.uri` module. 

The top-level `uri_` functions are my fault but we don't want to continue adding more. Because we need a `Uri` object too. That's out of scope for this PR, but just noting for reference.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2428,8 +2428,27 @@ vim.loader.reset({path})                                  *vim.loader.reset()*
 ==============================================================================
 Lua module: vim.uri                                                  *vim.uri*
 
+vim.uri_decode({str})                                       *vim.uri_decode()*
+    URI-decodes a string containing percent escapes.
+
+    Parameters: ~
+       {str}  (string) string to decode
+
+    Return: ~
+        (string) decoded string
+
+vim.uri_encode({str}, {rfc})                                *vim.uri_encode()*

comment_regular_data.body: Might be worth to add a test for one such edge case that is now disambiguated.

Example of edge-case ambiguous/aliased cache path:

```
/a/%/b.lua --> %a%%%b.lua
/a/%%b.lua --> %a%%%b.lua
```
Should be pretty much done. Lmk if there's anything else
Thanks for noticing this and fixing it. I'll introduce vim.uri in a followup PR (and address @lewis6991's comments there too).

title: fix(loader): cache path ambiguity
